title: How to Make Nasturtium Flower Vinegar

steps.headline: Place the nasturtium flowers into the jar.
Pour the apple cider vinegar over the flowers.
steps.description: Cover them and have a little extra vinegar over the top.

steps.headline: Add the lid.
steps.description: If the lid is metallic, line with plastic kitchen wrap to prevent corrosion. Label and date.

steps.headline: Place in a cool and dark place for infusion.
steps.description: Leave for about 2 to 4 weeks, taste testing after about 2 weeks.

steps.headline: Strain the flowers out of the vinegar.
steps.description: Use a fine sieve or pour through muslin, a coffee filter, etc. Pour into a glass storage bottle with lid. Straining is optional. If you prefer, you can continue adding new flowers and vinegar to keep the vinegar going over time.

steps.headline: Pour into a glass bottle.
steps.description: Store in a cold and dark place, or in the refrigerator.

steps.headline: Fill the jar with the nasturtium flowers.
Fill the jar with vinegar.
steps.description: Cover the jar and set aside. Let it steep for 1-2 days.

steps.headline: Top up with more vinegar.
steps.description: The flowers will decrease in size as they absorb the liquid and you can refill to the top.

steps.headline: Put a lid or cover on the jar and set it in a sunny place for 7-10 days.
Strain and bottle.
steps.description: Use when required in salad dressings and sauces to add a peppery touch.

steps.headline: Place the clean flowers and leaves into the jar.
steps.description: Add the rosemary and peppercorns too.

steps.headline: Pour the vinegar over the other ingredients.
Set aside.
steps.description: Let steep for 3 to 4 weeks. You can test the flavor after 2 weeks.

steps.headline: Strain the vinegar into a glass storage bottle.
steps.description: Use a fine sieve or muslin/cheesecloth. Discard the flowers and leaves.

steps.headline: Label and date.
steps.description: Store in a cool, dark place.

text: Nasturtium vinegar Place the nasturtium flowers into the jar.  Pour the apple cider vinegar over the flowers. Cover them and have a little extra vinegar over the top. Add the lid. If the lid is metallic, line with plastic kitchen wrap to prevent corrosion. Label and date. Place in a cool and dark place for infusion. Leave for about 2 to 4 weeks, taste testing after about 2 weeks. Strain the flowers out of the vinegar. Use a fine sieve or pour through muslin, a coffee filter, etc. Pour into a glass storage bottle with lid. Straining is optional. If you prefer, you can continue adding new flowers and vinegar to keep the vinegar going over time. Pour into a glass bottle. Store in a cold and dark place, or in the refrigerator. Nasturtium cayenne vinegar Fill the jar with the nasturtium flowers.  Add the cayenne and salt.  Fill the jar with vinegar. Cover the jar and set aside. Let it steep for 1-2 days. Top up with more vinegar. The flowers will decrease in size as they absorb the liquid and you can refill to the top. Put a lid or cover on the jar and set it in a sunny place for 7-10 days.  Strain and bottle. Use when required in salad dressings and sauces to add a peppery touch. Nasturtium peppercorn vinegar Place the clean flowers and leaves into the jar. Add the rosemary and peppercorns too. Pour the vinegar over the other ingredients. Add the lid. Set aside. Let steep for 3 to 4 weeks. You can test the flavor after 2 weeks. Strain the vinegar into a glass storage bottle. Use a fine sieve or muslin/cheesecloth. Discard the flowers and leaves. Label and date. Store in a cool, dark place.
